column6: Introduction to the nature and scope of educational service delivery across settings, and to the social and cultural foundations of educational policies and programs. Open to any university student and to those considering alternative careers in education.
Students utilize readings, explore themes, broadly explore purposes of school in society and what knowledge, dispositions and performances are necessary to be a successful teacher today.

column2: INTRODUCTION TO THE PHILOSOPHY OF EDUCATION
column6: An introduction to the philosophical analysis of educational problems focusing on the goals of education and the Department's role in achieving these goals.
Directed reading and/or research of special interest or need to small groups of students in cultural foundations. Planned with and directed by a faculty member. IP grade permissible.
Directed independent reading and/or research of special interest or need in student program. Planned with and directed by a faculty member.

column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN CULTURAL FOUNDATIONS
column6: Variable topics; designed to respond to specialized needs of various groups within the context of trends issues and problems in the educational foundations disciplines. S u graded.

Explores the history, social context, and issues in multicultural education (formal PK-12) in the U.S. Students gain an appreciation of the challenges of equalizing opportunity of educational achievement, an understanding that is essential for 21st century educational leadership.

column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN CULTURAL FOUNDATIONS
column6: Offered on request of school system. Enrollment limited to teachers, administrators or supervisors who are employed in sponsoring system and who are accepted to the university. May be repeated once for total maximum credit of six hours.

Explores the history, social context, and issues in multicultural education (formal PK-12) in the U.S. Students gain an appreciation of the challenges of equalizing opportunity of educational achievement, an understanding that is essential for 21st century educational leadership.
Thesis student must register for total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a single semester distributed over several semesters if desired.
Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree requirements are met.

column2: FOUNDATIONS OF EDUCATION AND HUMAN SERVICES
column6: Inquiry into the assumptions and implications of educational policies and practices in education and human service settings through the application of historical, philosophical and sociological perspectives.

column2: PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE IN A MULTICULTURAL SOCIETY
column6: Interdisciplinary inquiry into issues of pluralism and its influence on professional practice in education and human service settings. Cross-cultural interaction will be analyzed; reflection on developing culturally responsive professional practice.

column2: PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE IN A MULTICULTURAL SOCIETY
column6: Interdisciplinary inquiry into issues of pluralism and its influence on professional practice in education and human service settings. Cross-cultural interaction will be analyzed; reflection on developing culturally responsive professional practice.
An examination of ethics in departmenting and other educational settings through foundational study and issue analysis; strong case study and professional application emphasis.

column2: MULTICULTURAL THEORIES AND SCHOLARSHIP IN EDUCATION
column6: An investigation of multicultural theories in education, the social sciences and humanities as articulated in the works of major scholars. Approaches to research and scholarship and contemporary issues in public discourse is explored.

column2: HIGHER EDUCATION IN THE UNITED STATES
column6: Examines the historical, philosophical, social, political and economic roots of current programs, policies, practices and commitments of institutions of higher education in the United States.

Explores a range of contemporary philosophical perspectives on the moral and political dimensions of education. Students will be introduced to the philosophical frameworks through which these questions are discussed within the field of philosophy of education and they will have opportunity to engage these debates in the course of carefully structured writing assignments.
European origins and American innovations in colonial education, rise of common Department, completion of education ladder. Emphasis is on present status and recent developments.
Educational ideals and practices of European and Western civilizations in their historical contexts. Evaluation of their influence on present educational thought and practice.

Overview and exploration of history of higher education in the United States. Survey course covers ancient and medieval European antecedents but focuses largely on American Higher Education from the seventeenth through the 20th century. Students explore changes in student body, curricula and purposes of higher education in the U.S. in the context of American culture.

column4: Special approval of instructor and graduate standing.
column6: An examination of major influential ideas in education through original sources from Plato to Skinner.

An introductory seminar to explore current foundational issues and challenges in education worldwide (non-formal, formal PK-advanced post-secondary education). Students gain an understanding of the socio-political, historical context of education worldwide and implications for local policy formation. An international-comparative approach connects and integrates cross-cultural literature, theoretical and research scholarship, on the impact of world dynamics on education. Students also explore the impact of education on economies and social compacts worldwide, with attention to inequalities or marginalities based on region, social status, ethnicity, race, religion, gender and disability.

Theoretical foundations of cultural pluralism, structural marginalization processes, knowledge construction, equity pedagogy and praxis in intercultural relations, democratic change processes and policy addressing inequities in institutional practices.
A multi-disciplinary exploration of the impact of globalization/localization on the delivery and uses of education and the dynamics of power and resistance in globalized education.

Students explore the contributions that cultural and social anthropologists have made to the study of education broadly conceived, focusing particularly on studies addressing the interrelationships among education, culture and forms of social inequity. Through engaging in critical readings of classic and contemporary educational ethnographics, students explore the myriad ways in which "culture" has been theoretically conceptualized as well as the implications of those conceptualizations for educational inquiry and practice.
Variable topic seminar for advanced study of specialized topics and areas; in cultural foundations; emphasis on theory and research findings as related to educational practice.

column2: ADVANCED PRACTICUM AND INTERNSHIP IN CULTURAL FOUNDATIONS
column6: Supervised program in field setting involving application of theories, principles and methodology in cultural foundations of education; planned with and supervised by graduate faculty member.
Specific topic course offering in response to emerging student or program needs in cultural foundations of education.
Students pursue an individual project on a specific topic in cultural foundations of education with approval and under direction of instructor.
Students pursue an individual research project on a specific topic in cultural foundations of education with approval and under direction of instructor.

column2: VARIABLE TOPIC WORKSHOP IN CULTURAL FOUNDATIONS
column6: Offered on request of school system. Enrollment limited to teachers, administrators or supervisors who are employed in sponsoring system and who are accepted to the university. May be repeated once for total maximum credit of six hours.
Analysis of selected philosophies of education through examination of philosophical problems of education.

column2: MULTICULTURAL THEORIES AND SCHOLARSHIP IN EDUCATION
column6: An investigation of multicultural theories in education, the social sciences and humanities as articulated in the works of major scholars. Approaches to research and scholarship and contemporary issues in public discourse is explored.

column2: HIGHER EDUCATION IN THE UNITED STATES
column6: Examines the historical, philosophical, social, political and economic roots of current programs, policies, practices and commitments of institutions of higher education in the United States.
The impact of the federal constitution, statutes and case law on public education is studied. Historical intent and current application of related laws are included.

Explores a range of contemporary philosophical perspectives on the moral and political dimensions of education. Students will be introduced to the philosophical frameworks through which these questions are discussed within the field of philosophy of education and they will have opportunity to engage these debates in the course of carefully structured writing assignments.
European origins and American innovations in colonial education, rise of common Department, completion of education ladder. Emphasis is on present status and recent developments.
Educational ideals and practices of European and Western civilizations in their historical contexts. Evaluation of their influence on present educational thought and practice.

Overview and exploration of history of higher education in the United States. Survey course covers ancient and medieval European antecedents but focuses largely on American Higher Education from the seventeenth through the 20th century. Students explore changes in student body, curricula and purposes of higher education in the U.S. in the context of American culture.

column4: Special approval of instructor and doctoral standing.
column6: An examination of major influential ideas in education through original sources from Plato to Skinner.

An introductory seminar to explore current foundational issues and challenges in education worldwide (non-formal, formal PK-advanced post-secondary education). Students gain an understanding of the socio-political, historical context of education worldwide and implications for local policy formation. An international-comparative approach connects and integrates cross-cultural literature, theoretical and research scholarship, on the impact of world dynamics on education. Students also explore the impact of education on economies and social compacts worldwide, with attention to inequalities or marginalities based on region, social status, ethnicity, race, religion, gender and disability. Gaining a broad understanding of the place of education in a rapidly changing world is essential for 21st century educational leadership and the formation of constructive policies for the future of both developed and developing countries.

Theoretical foundations of cultural pluralism, structural marginalization processes, knowledge construction, equity pedagogy and praxis in intercultural relations, democratic change processes and policy addressing inequities in institutional practices.
A multi-disciplinary exploration of the impact of globalization/localization on the delivery and uses of education and the dynamics of power and resistance in globalized education.

Students explore the contributions that cultural and social anthropologists have made to the study of education broadly conceived, focusing particularly on studies addressing the interrelationships among education, culture and forms of social inequity. Through engaging in critical readings of classic and contemporary educational ethnographies, students explore the myriad ways in which "culture" had been theoretically conceptualized, as well as the implications of those conceptualizations for educational inquiry and practice.
Methods of legal research, case analysis and a "uniform system of citation" are studied.
Advanced doctoral residency seminar for students in all areas of educational foundations. Focus on current and emergent issues research and trends in education in multiple settings.

column4: Open to doctoral students from any field.
column6: Interdisciplinary review of current great issues in education that are catalogs for presentation after discussion with membership of the course.

Doctoral dissertation for which registration in at least two semesters is required, first of which will be semester in which dissertation work is begun and continuing until the completion of 30 hours.
Continuing registration required of doctoral students who have completed the initial 30 hours of dissertation and continuing until all degree requirements are met.

Comprehensive analysis of issues affecting professional practice in education and human service resource settings. Examination of questions related to inter-professional collaboration on policy, research and practice.
Comparative analysis of contemporary educational policies and structures in large-and small scale societies throughout the world.

Doctoral seminar to familiarize PhD students with cultural and social foundations of education as a field of study so that they may locate their inquiry within the relevant knowledge base and academic disciplines that comprise the cultural foundations of education.
Examines selected social factors that influence the development of educational policies and patterns of research relating to school and non-school educational settings.
Variable topic seminar for advanced study of specialized topics and areas in cultural foundations; emphasis on theory and research findings as related to educational practice.

column6: Supervised program in field setting involving application of theories, principles and methodology in cultural foundations of education; planned with and supervised by graduate faculty member.

Students pursue an individual project on a specific topic in cultural foundations of education with approval and under direction of instructor.
